Q. Before you left him did any others come in - A. Miles M'Cabe came in.
Q. Anybody else - A. No, I did not see anybody else.
Q. Did anybody else come in - A. I do not recollect.
Q. Do you swear that - A. Yes.
Q. Then nobody else came in - A. Not for a great while after M'Cabe came.
Q. Did anybody else come in before Miles M'Cabe left A. No, I really cannot recollect.

Q. While you was with
Edward Crane
, did anybody else come in - A. I cannot recollect.
Q. Did M'Cabe bring any thing - A. He brought a bundle.
Q. Was it large or small - A. Very small.
Q. What did it contain - A. I do not know; I did not look at it.
Q. Did it contain linen, or boxes, or iron, or what - A. I do not know.
Q. Was it dry or wet - A. I do not know; I did not take notice.
Q. How long was it in your sight - A. While I was there.
Q. How long were you there - A. Only a quarter of an hour.
Q. You was there only a quarter of an hour after Miles M'Cabe came in - A. No, only a quarter of an hour.
Q. During that quarter of an hour that you was there, I ask you, on your oath, did anybody else come into the same room with you and M'Cabe while you was there - A. I really cannot say.
Q. You are called upon as a witness to speak the truth, I now ask you if anybody else came in - A. I really cannot say.
Q. Did you tell the truth when you was at Bow-street - A. I do not know.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

732.
MILES M'CABE
and
DANIEL CRANE
were again indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of March , one tablecloth, value 5 s. , the goods of
Robert Beattie
.

ANN BEATTIE
. I am the wife of
Robert Beattie
, who lives at No. 1, Pratt-street, Camden-town
. On the 5th of March, about half-past three o'clock in the afternoon, I lost this table-cloth out of the garden at the back of the house, which is fenced by railing four feet high; I saw it safe ten minutes before. About three weeks after, the officer brought it - the prisoners were in custody.

THOMAS WADMORE
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Tottenham-court-road with my brother. On the 8th of March, the table-cloth was pledged with me by
Mary Ann Wilson
, who was examined in the last case.

JOHN DAVIS
.
Mary Ann Wilson
took me to the shop where the table-cloth was pledged, after the prisoners were taken up.

ROBERT BEATTIE
. I was coming out of my house a little after three o'clock in the afternoon, and saw a young man inside my garden railing; one or two of the railings were broken - I made him come out - the linen was hanging up to dry. There was another man standing by the railing - they both went away. I do not know them.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

733.
JOHN MURPHY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of March , one coat, value 14 s., and one handkerchief, value 1 s. , the goods of
Joseph Sayer
.

JOSEPH SAYER
. I live in Old Gravel-lane, and am carman to Messrs. Sharp and Co. On the 29th of March, in the afternoon, I missed my coat out of the yard; it was adark snuff coloured coat. My fellow-servant lost another coat.

ROBERT REDMAN
. I am a carman. I was near the stable, and saw the prisoner come out of the yard with two coats on his shoulder. He ran by me into Old Gravel-lane.

ELIZA LITTLE
. I was at work opposite the stable, and saw the prisoner go into the yard, and come out with two coats over his shoulder - I am sure he is the man. He had no coat when he went in.

WILLIAM SIMMS
. I am a constable. I apprehended the prisoner.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Whipped , and Discharged.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

734.
HENRY ROBERTS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of February , one sheet, value 6 s. , the goods of
John Radley
.

JOHN RADLEY
. I am a gardener , and live at Bow
. On the 26th of February, I was in my garden, and heard some persons call out, that a man had robbed me; I turned round and saw the prisoner running. He threw the sheet down, and I collared him. It hung on a line at the door.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Fined One Shilling , and Discharged.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

735.
SARAH SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of March , 2 lbs. of flock, value 6 d.; two blankets, value 6 s.; one mattress-case, value 2 s., and one rug, value 2 s., the goods of
John Morris
, in a lodging-room .

ELIZA MORRIS
. I am the wife of
John Morris
, who keeps the Old Crown, public-house , Webb-square, Shoreditch
. I let the prisoner a two-pair front-room, furnished, at 3 s. 6 d. a week - she came on the 18th of March. Next morning, I saw her come down with a bundle under her arm; she told my husband on the evening of the 18th, that she wanted to go out early in the morning, and I showed her how to open the door. Next day, about five o'clock I looked through a hole in the door, and saw the flock laying about the room. About seven o'clock my husband went up stairs, intending to go into the room; she said every thing was right, but the things were dirty. I went in with the constable, and missed the property stated in the indictment. The bed was emptied, mattress, and tick and all were sold - they were let to her with the lodgings.

SARAH ACKELEY
. I am a broker, and live in Club-row, Spitalfields. On the 17th of March, I bought the bed-stick and bolster of the prisoner, for 2 s. 6 d. Next day I bought a mattress-tick and 2 lbs. of flock for 1 s. 6 d., I also bought two blankets of her. She said that she lived in Webb-square,
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. The woman said I should have them back again for a few halfpence more.
GUILTY . Aged 39.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

736.
SAMUEL HAWKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of March , one petticoat, value 2 s. the goods of
Peter Hill
.

MARGARET HILL
. I am the wife of Peter Hill, who lives at Bromley
. On the 12th of March, I saw a man take my petticoat off the line, and run off. The prisoner was brought back in about ten minutes, and gave it to me.

EDWARD HEGAN
. I heard the alarm, and secured the prisoner with the petticoat under his coat.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I bought it for 4 d.
GUILTY . Aged 46.

Confined Six Months , and
Whipped .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

737.
MARY ANN JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of March , nine towels, value 5 s., and two petticoats, value 3 s. , the goods of
Sarah Taylor
, widow .

SARAH TAYLOR
. I am a widow, and live in Charles-street, Hatton-garden
. On the 9th of March, between four and five o'clock in the afternoon, these things hung in my parlour to dry; the door was a little ajar - I was backward. The prisoner pushed the screen aside, and my daughter said there was a woman; I saw the prisoner going out; she said she wanted Mrs. Gregory - I said she did not live there. My daughter said she had got all the things under her arm - she said they were Mrs. Gregory's things. I pulled her into the room, and took them from under her arm - she had got to the door.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I asked for Mrs. Cotterill.
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

738.
CHARLES HOLLOWAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of April , one saw, value 8 s., the goods of
Samuel Scales
; one saw, value 8 s., and one rule, value 3 s. , the goods of
William Brazier
.

JOHN TAYLOR
. I am a carpenter, and live at Heston
; the prisoner was a gentleman's servant . On the 5th of April, at night, my shutters were broken open, and these tools taken - Scales and Brazier work at my shop. The staple was drawn, and every thing taken out of my shop. I suppose it was done about two o'clock in the night, as I heard a noise about that time, and got up, but saw nothing.

SAMUEL SCALES
. I lost my tools out of the shop - they were safe the night before.

WILLIAM BRAZIER
. I lost my tools the same night.

RICHARD RAVENER
. I am a constable. On the 6th of April, I took the prisoner, at the Coach and Horses, at Hanwell, and found the tools upon him. He offered them all to me for sale for 10 s.; he sold them to a carpenter in the room for 7 s. - I secured him. He said his name was Hiscock, which I knew to be false.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I bought them for 6 s.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

739.
JOHN WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of February , one musket, value 7 s. , the goods of
William Haggett
.

WILLIAM HAGGETT
. I am a labourer , and live in Essex-court, Park-street, Borough
. On the 24th of February, between ten and eleven o'clock in the morning, I missed my musket out of the passage. I went after the prisoner, and took him at Ratcliff-cross, between twelve and one o'clock that day, with the musket on his arm. I was informed he had gone that way, pursued him, and took him. I am certain he is the man.

JOSEPH ADAMS
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner in charge on the 24th of February, with the musket. He made his escape from the office, and was taken again. I am sure he is the man.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

- I am an officer. I was bringing the prisoner to Newgate; he broke from me and ran down Newgate-market - I lost him, but retook him again about fifteen days after, and am sure he is the man. He had the marks of the handcuffs on his wrist that he ran away with.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

740.
THOMAS JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of April , two coats, value 5 l. , the property of
George Smith
.

SUSAN SMITH
. I am the daughter of
George Smith
, who is a labourer , and lives at Hackney
. I was crossing the road, and saw the prisoner with two coats under his arm. I ran in, and missed my father's coats from behind the door; I pursued him, calling Stop thief! and a gentleman stopped him. I am certain he is the man.

SUSAN POWELL
. The prisoner ran by me with the coats under his arm; the last witness called Stop thief! he jumped into the hedge of a garden, left the coats there, and returned without them. The constable stopped him. I never lost sight of him.

THOMAS GOODWIN
. I am a constable. I stopped the prisoner, who was running in Grove-street. He said there was nothing amiss, it was only a joke; I took him back and found the coats in the hedge.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I saw a man run into the garden with a bundle, and pursued him, but lost him.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

741.
MICHAEL GARATTY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of April , three yards and a half of velveteen, value 9 s., the goods of
George William Rainbow
, from his person .

GEORGE WILLIAM RAINBOW
. I am a tailor . On the 22d of April, about half-past two o'clock in the day, I was behind a coach, in the Commercial-road
. In about a minute the prisoner and another man came up - the prisoner sat by my side. In a little time he took my bundle from under my arm; I told him to let it alone - he revised to give it to me, and said it was a joke. He struck me several blows about the head, and gave the bundle to his companion, who ran away with it. I got down and pursued him; he then turned back, and gave it to the prisoner on the coach; they knocked me down, and struck me several blows. I took it from them, and took the prisoner into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. LOVET. Q. There were a great many people in the road at the time - A. A great many. The prisoner continued sitting on the coach. He did not ask me to make room for his companion.

WILLIAM PARSONS
. I was passing, and saw a man give the bundle to the prisoner, who was riding behind the coach - the prisoner knocked the prosecutor down. I stopped to look at them, and took the prisoner to the office. I believe he was the worse for liquor.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I had been drinking; the prosecutor grumbled at my coming behind the coach, and knocked my hat off; I took his parcel and threw it after my hat, another man came, and took both hat and bundle.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

742.
JOHN MORGAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of March , one coat, value 25 s.; one pair of gloves, value 6 d., and one umbrella, value 4 s. 6 d. , the goods of
Samuell Waller
.

SAMUEL WALLER
. I am a cooper , and live at Wapping. I left my coat and umbrella in the counting-house of Messrs. Osman and Co. - it was stolen.

WILLIAM MORBEY
. I am a carman. On the 26th of March, about eleven o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner come out of the counting-house, with the coat and umbrella; he said Mr. Donegal had sent him for them. I collared him, and took him back. He offered me his own coat to let him go.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I was in distress.
GUILTY. Aged 24.

Judgment Respited
.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

743.
DANIEL MAHONEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of April , one handkerchief, value 15 d., the goods of
Henry Beverly Wakeling
, from his person .

HENRY BEVERLY WAKELING
. On the 23d of April, about eight o'clock in the evening, I was in Drury-lane
with Mr. Young; the prisoner and another were following us very close. I felt a hand in my pocket, turned round and collared the prisoner - his companion ran away. My handkerchief was not found; I had it a moment before. I am certain I caught the prisoner's hand in my pocket.

JOHN YOUNG
. I was with Wakeling; he said he had lost his handkerchief, and seized the prisoner - the other ran away. Nobody else had been near us.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Confined Six Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

744.
MARGARET MALONEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of April , one tea-caddy, value 2 s. 6 d. , the goods of
Alexander Adams
, the elder .

ALEXANDER ADAMS
, JUN. I am the son of
Alexander Adams
, who lives at Hackney
. On the 1st of April, I heard the door shut, missed the tea-caddy, and secured the prisoner in the road with it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I sold the prosecutor's wife a pint of brandy; she told me to take the caddy, until she could pay me.

ELIZA ADAMS
. I am the wife of
Alexander Adams
. I never saw the prisoner before.
GUILTY . Aged 35.
Confined Six Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

745.
JOHN MALBOROUGH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of March , two coats, value 4 s., and one spencer, value 6 d., the goods of
John Butterworth
; and one coat, value 5 s. , the goods of
William Hayman
.

ANN BUTTERWORTH
. I am the wife of
John Butterworth
, who is a weigher in the Custom House . On the 16th of March, between eight and nine o'clock in the morning, the coats were in the butler's pantry, at a gentleman's house which I have the care of, in Marlborough-street
. My little girl called me; I ran and saw the prisoner in the passage with tracts in his hand, which he wanted to sell. I sent him away, and told him he should have knocked at the door; I bolted the door, and saw him with the coats, on the area steps. I pursued him, and secured him in the street with them - one belongs to
William Hayman
, and the other is my husband's.

MARY ANN GOSS
. I heard the last witness call out Stop thief! and assisted in securing the prisoner.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

746.
THOMAS POWELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of March , two spoons, value 4 s. 9 d., and 12 s. in copper monies numbered , the property of
Michael Brown
.

MICHAEL BROWN
. I am a tailor , and live in James-street
. On the 14th of March, about four o'clock, I went out with my wife - I returned about five, found my parlour window open, and the canary bird taken away, with two spoons, and 12 s. in copper. I saw the prisoner in the passage calling to the lodgers - he was apprehended next morning. I found my spoons at a silversmith's in Cheapside - I knew the prisoner before.

THOMAS THOMPSON
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner at a public-house on Saffron-hill. I told him I took him for stealing the spoons - he said he sold them in Cheapside, and told me where to find the bird.

JAMES STEVENS
. I am clerk to Mr. Bull, who is a silversmith, and lives in Cheapside. I bought two spoons of a boy about the age of the prisoner, for 4 s. 9 d. I did not ask him any questions.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Six Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

747.
JOHN THOMAS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of April , 60 lbs. of lead, value 20 s. , the goods of
William Marshall
.

WILLIAM MARSHALL
. I am a plumber . On the 15th of April this lead stood at my door. I went to dinner about one o'clock, returned at two, and saw the prisoner walking by the door with the lead on his shoulder. I followed him, he threw it down, and I secured him without losing sight of him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

WILLIAM WIBER
. I am a constable. I assisted in securing the prisoner.
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

748.
CHARLES THOMPSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of April , 56 lbs. of mutton, value 30 s. , the property of
William Robbins
.

WILLIAM ROBBINS
. I am a butcher , and live in High-street, Shadwell
. On the 24th of April, about a quarter before five o'clock in the morning, a young man, named
James Stevens
, knocked at my door, and informed me that my place was broken open. I ran down, found the door open, and missed a carcase of mutton - it was double-jointed all round, which was very remarkable - I never saw one like it before. I afterwards found the whole carcase cut up very badly, and can swear to it. I fitted the joints to it.

ROBERT HICKS
. I am a patrol of Old Gravel-lane. On the 24th of April, about a quarter after four o'clock in the morning, I found the prisoner laying down in a twine-shed, with his head on a bag. I asked him what he was doing there? he said he had laid down to sleep. I asked him what he had got in his bag? he said it was some rags. I found there were two fore-quarters and four other pieces of mutton - he said he found it in the West India Docks.

JOHN PATERSON
. I am a watchman. About a quarter after four o'clock in the morning of the 24th of April, Hicks brought the prisoner to me. I went into the shed, and found the hind part of the mutton hanging up about four yards from where he laid.

WILLIAM STEVENS
. On the 24th of April, about a quarter before five o'clock in the morning, I was looking through the window, and saw the prosecutor's door open; I went down, found the staple had been drawn, and gave the alarm.

WILLIAM SUMMERS
. I am a constable. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house. I found two kidnies and a large spike nail on him, and two knives, one in each stocking - I also found some fat in a bag in his hat. The prosecutor saw the mutton, and compared it with one of the knuckles - it corresponded exactly; it was double-jointed.
GUILTY . Aged 36.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

749.
DANIEL AUSTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of March , two candlesticks, value 2 s. , the goods of
Thomas Eagles
.

SARAH EAGLES
. I am the wife of
Thomas Eagles
; we keep a chandler's shop . I went out to speak to a little boy, and on coming back I saw the prisoner in the shop, and asked him what he wanted? he asked me if I wanted to buy a cheese-knife? I said No. When he was gone, I missed a pair of candlesticks off the counter. I ran out, and overtook him - he gave them to me instantly. He appeared in distress.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 39.
Fined One Shilling , and Discharged.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

750.
MARY KELLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of March , one 5 l. bank note, the property of
James Chubb
, from his person .

JAMES CHUBB
. I am a harness-maker , and live at Holloway. On the 15th of March, about eleven o'clock, I was at the Lord Nelson, public-house, Shoreditch
, the prisoner and two others were there - they asked me to give them a glass of gin. I offered the landlady a 5 l. note to pay for it - the prisoner snatched it out of my hand, put it down towards her pocket-hole, and would not deliver it up. The watchman took her - it was not found. She said if I would go to her house she would give me the note.

MARGARET HOARE
. I keep the Lord Nelson. I was in the bar, and saw the prisoner snatch the note out of the prosecutor's hand.
ANN M'DERMOT. I was with the prisoner. She snatched the note out of the prosecutor's hand. He treated me with a glass of gin.
Prisoner's Defence. I met him in the City-road - he took me to the house. I never saw the note.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

751.
CATHARINE MARTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of April , one breeches-piece, value 3 s., and one handkerchief, value 2 s. , the goods of
John Robson
.

JOHN ROBSON
. I am a tailor , and live in Glass-house-yard
. On the 14th of April I lost these things from my drawers.

WILLIAM BROCKLEY
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 15th of April the prisoner pledged the breeches piece and handkerchief with me.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I pledged them for my master's son, who was in distress.
GUILTY . Aged 49.
Fined One Shilling , and Discharged.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

752.
RICHARD PRATT
was indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Richard Love
, about nine o'clock at night of the 29th of March
, with intent to steal, and burglariously stealing therein, one coat, value 40 s.; one waistcoat, value 5 s.; one pair of breeches, value 13 s.; 33 yards of gauze, value 3 l.; six shirts, value 30 s.; three gowns, value 20 s.; two suits of clothes, value 20 s.; one pair of gloves, value 1 s.; one shawl, value 20 s.; two pincloths, value 1 s.; two handkerchiefs, value 2 s.; one pair of boots, value 4 s.; 4 l. in monies numbered, and fourteen 1 l. bank notes , his property; and
ELIZABETH PETHERS
was indicted for
feloniously receiving one shawl, one waistcoat, one pair of gloves, two handkerchiefs, and one pair of boots, part and parcel of the aforesaid goods, she well knowing them to have been stolen .
MR. ALLEY, on the part of the prosecution, declined offering any evidence.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

753.
ELIZABETH BRIAN
and
ANN GRIFFIN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of March , 9 lbs. of bacon, value 6 s. , the goods of
Thomas Gammage
.

THOMAS GAMMAGE
. I am a cheesemonger , and live in King-street, Seven Dials
. On the 23d of March the prisoners came to the shop three or four times in the afternoon, and laid out about three halfpence. They came again at six o'clock. The moment they went away I missed the bacon, and sent my man after them.

SAMUEL RUDMAN
. I ran out and secured the prisoners together about ten yards off. Griffin had the bacon.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

BRIAN -
GUILTY . Aged 38.

GRIFFIN -
GUILTY . Aged 39.
Confined Six Months .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

754.
JOHN AUSTIN EATON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of March , one rummer glass, value 18 d. , the goods of
George Parry
.

GEORGE PARRY
. I keep the Duke's Head, public-house , in Norton-falgate
. On the 22d of March the prisoner came into my house, and had a glass of stout. I missed the glass, and asked him if he had seen it? he said the lady had taken it. I found it in his pocket, and two others in his hat. He was rather in liquor.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was intoxicated.
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Fined One Shilling , and Discharged.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

755.
JANE WOODEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of March , two gowns, value 12 s.; one sheet, value 5 s.; one shift, value 5 s., and one sheet, value 6 s. , the goods of
Simon Levy
.

ELIZA LEVY
. I am the wife of
Simon Levy
, we live in Three Tun-alley, Whitechapel
. On the 16th of March I hired the prisoner as my servant - on that very morning I missed these things, with others. I lost four sheets, but only found one. I only left her in the house an hour, and when I returned she had absconded with the property, and left my child crying in the house alone.

JAMES WALTER
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a sheet, a bed-gown, and a shift, which the prisoner pledged with me on the 16th of March.

JOHN JOHNSON
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 16th of March the prisoner pledged a shirt with me.
FRANCIS FREEMAN. On the 16th of March I found a gown on the prisoner.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. Distress drove me to it.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

756.
GEORGE SCONE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of April , one handkerchief, value 1 s., the goods of
Henry James Brooks
, from his person .

HENRY JAMES BROOKS
. On the 27th of April, about ten o'clock at night, I was in Holborn
with
John Mullins
, who said a person was picking my pocket - I felt, and missed my handkerchief. I turned round, and saw the prisoner throw something white away, but am not certain that it was my handkerchief. I collared him, and called Watch! he struck me three times, and ran off, but was stopped. My handkerchief was not found.
Cross-examined by MR. ALLEY. Q. Did you not charge him with an assault - A. No.

JOHN MULLINS
. I was with Brooks, and saw the prisoner behind him. I suspected him, and informed the prosecutor - he never collared the prisoner. I went back to look for the handkerchief, but it was gone.

FRANCIS GAMMAGE
. I am a watchman. I heard the alarm, and stopped the prisoner. He said it was only a row.
Prisoner's Defence. The prosecutor collared me - I pushed him off, he struck me, and I struck him.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

757.
GEORGE M'LEAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of April , 7 lbs. of pork, value 3 s. , the goods of
Robert Pilkington
.

SUSAN PILKINGTON
. I am the wife of
Robert Pilkington
, who is a pork-butcher , and lives in Chandos-street
. On the 27th of April, between nine and ten o'clock in the evening, the prisoner came into the shop, reached over the counter, and took a leg of pork. I secured him with it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was in distress.
GUILTY . Aged 58.
Confined One Month .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

758.
JAMES KING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of March , one spade, value 3 s. , the goods of
Robert Doe
.

WILLIAM BIGNAL
. I am servant to
Robert Doe
, who is a cow-keeper . On the 2d of March, the prisoner came out of the cow-house with a spade. I collared him, and he threw it down.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was never near the cow-house.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

759.
THOMAS HARRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of April , one handkerchief, value 2 s., from the person of a man
whose name is unknown .

THOMAS STEVENS
. I am a potatoe salesman in Covent-garden
. On the 17th of April, at half-past eleven o'clock at night, I was taking my scales and weights to the public-house, and saw the prisoner and another young man rush out of the door as I went in; as I returned to Covent-garden I saw them again about twenty yards from the door, the prisoner took a handkerchief from a gentleman's pocket, turned back again, and went into the public-house - I followed him, and stood by the door; he came out again with the same young man - they went up the street, and both stood against a railing in the street. I passed them, three gentlemen and a lady came by, returning from the Theatre, they both followed them, and I saw the prisoner take the handkerchief from the gentleman's pocket - it was a blue and white one. I pointed him out to the watchman. I am certain he is the man.
Q. Why did you not stop the gentleman, and tell him - A. Because I was once robbed myself, and when I took the man I was surrounded by a gang of about twenty, and got almost killed.

CHARLES HUMPHRIES
. On the 17th of April I was with Bond under the Piazza, and met a watchman, who pointed the prisoner out to me in a public-house, I beckoned him out, searched him, and found a blue and white handkerchief in his hat; he said he had had it almost a fortnight - it smelt very strong of perfume; he said it was not marked, but it was. Bond found another handkerchief on him.
WILLIAM BOND. I searched the prisoner, and found a handkerchief in his side-pocket; he said it was not marked, but it was.
Prisoner's Defence. They are both my own.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Life .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

760.
ROBERT ASHBY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of March , one ham, value 6 s. , the property of
John Charles Lea
.

JAMES PERCIVAL
. I am servant to
John Charles Lea
, who is a cheesemonger , at Hackney
. I missed a ham from the door, ran out, and found the prisoner with it under his jacket.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was in distress.
GUILTY . Aged 62.
Fined One Shilling , and Discharged.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

761.
DAVID MORGAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of February , three blankets, value 15 s.; two sheets, value 6 s.; one table-cloth, value 2 s.; one apron, value 6 d., and one waistcoat, value 1 s. , the goods of
Philip Mark
.

PHILLIP MARK
. I am a tailor , and live in High Holborn
; the prisoner was my porter , and his wife was my housekeeper. On the 11th of March I missed some property, and had them both searched. I found a pocketbook on his wife containing twenty-four duplicates. The prisoner said he pledged the articles, and gave his wife the duplicates.

WILLIAM THISSLETON
. I am a constable. The prisoner and his wife were given into my charge. I found the duplicates of the property in the pocket-book.

THOMAS WINDSOR
ALLEN. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Clare-street. The prisoner pledged three blankets, two sheets, a table-cloth, an apron, and a waistcoat, with me, at different times.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 57.
Confined One Year .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

762.
LAWRENCE PERRIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of March , one handkerchief, value 18 d., the property of
Thomas Clark
, from his person .

THOMAS CLARK
. I live in Bernard's Inn, Holborn. Between eight and nine o'clock in the evening, I was in Drury-lane
; I was called and missed my handkerchief - it was produced to me.

THOMAS THOMPSON
. I am a constable. I was in Wych-street, and saw the prisoner following the prosecutor, who had a gentleman with him. I watched him, and saw him pull the handkerchief out a little way; he turned round to look about him - I was on the opposite side of the way. He then took it quite out; Forbes, who was with me secured him, and took it out of his bosom. I informed the prosecutor.

JOHN FORBES
. I am a constable. I was with Thompson, and saw the prisoner following the prosecutor; I crossed over, and saw him take the handkerchief partly out; he then turned round looked behind him, and took it quite out - he put it in his bosom. I laid hold of him, and took it out of his bosom.

CHARLES JONES
. I was with Forbes, and saw the handkerchief taken from the prisoner's bosom.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I picked it up.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Life .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

763.
JOHN MAYWOOD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of March , one wheelbarrow, value 15 s. , the goods of
William Mobbs
.

WILLIAM MOBBS
. I lost my wheelbarrow, but know nothing about it. Freeman who does is not here.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

764.
SARAH LONG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of April , one coat, value 2 s., and one waistcoat, value 6 d. , the goods of
James Elliott
.

ALICE ELLIOTT
. I am the wife of
James Elliott
; we live in Granby's-buildings, Drury-lane
. On the 25th of April, I lost this coat and waistcoat from the kitchen; next morning the prisoner passed at the bottom of the court; I secured her, and charged her with stealing them. She denied it.

ANN CRAWLEY
. I saw the prisoner come out of the prosecutor's door with the coat. I am sure she is the woman.

LEWIS SAMUEL
. I am a salesman, and live in Drury-lane. I bought the coat and waistcoat of the prisoner.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Fined One Shilling , and Discharged.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

765.
JOHN HURLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of April , one stewpan, value 10 s. , the goods of
Peter Markland
.

PETER MARKLAND
. I live in Green-street, St. George's in the East
; the prisoner lived next door to me. On the 24th of April, I lost this stewpan out of an outhouse. On the Monday he was taken, and it was produced to me.

SAMUEL WILLIAMS
. I am a seaman. On the 24th of April, I saw the prisoner in the prosecutor's yard, about seven o'clock in the morning; he took the stewpan, and put it over into his own yard - I live opposite, and am certain he is the man.

JOHN SMITHERS
. I am a carman. I bought the pan of a boy for 4 s.
JOHN BROWN. I apprehended the prisoner, concealed between his bed and mattress.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

766.
BENJAMIN FIRBY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of April , eight yards of oil-cloth, value 20 s. , the goods of
John Harrell
.

JOHN HARRELL
. I live in East-street, Marylebone
, and am a broker . I lost my oil-cloth, ran out and secured the prisoner with it, about four hundred yards off. He said a man gave it to him to carry.

WILLIAM BAILEY
. I live opposite Harrell. I saw another man take the oil-cloth, and give it to a man; the prisoner was secured.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. A man gave it to me to carry.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

767.
JOHN ANNS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of April , one handkerchief, value 5 s., the goods of
Thomas Dugard
, from his person ,

THOMAS DUGARD
. I am a goldsmith , and live in Red-Lion-street, Clerkenwell. On the 25th of April, about one o'clock I was crossing from Sadler's Wells into St. John-street-road
, a man called to me that my pocket had been picked; I found my handkerchief on the ground, and the prisoner close by me. I stopped him as he was pointed out to me; he said he knew nothing about it - nobody else was near me.

HENRY GREEN
. I am a carpenter, and live in Hermitage-place,Sadler's Wells. I saw the prisoner walking behind the prosecutor in the road - I saw him put his hand into Mr. Dugard's pocket, and pull the handkerchief out. I called out to the prosecutor - he immediately dropped it. The prosecutor stopped him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Life .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

768.
SARAH AFFLECK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of February , one tea-kettle, value 18 d. , the goods of
William Thomas
.

WILLIAM THOMAS
. I live at Mutton-hill
, and am a tool-broker . I missed a tea-kettle from my door, ran out, and secured the prisoner with it.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I was in distress.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Fined One Shilling , and Discharged.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.
